entries.question/paper_id: J560 02 Paper 2 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
15  Sam and two friends put letters in envelopes on Monday.  
    The three of them take two hours to put 600 letters in envelopes.

(a)  On Tuesday Sam has three friends helping.  
     Working at the same rate, how many letters should the four of them  
     be able to put in envelopes in two hours?  
     (a) …………………………………… [2]

(b)  Working at the same rate, how much longer would it take four people  
     to put 1000 letters in envelopes than it would take five people?  
     (b) …………………………………… [4]

(c)  Sam says:  
     “It took two hours for three people to put 600 letters in envelopes.  
      If I assume they work all day, then in one day three people will put  
      7200 letters in envelopes because 600 × 12 = 7200.”  

     Why is Sam’s assumption not reasonable?  
     What effect has Sam’s assumption had on her answer?  
     …………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………  
     ………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………… [2]

question/provided_answer.a: Firstly, 3 people can put 600 letters in envelopes in 2 hours. So in 2 hours, 1 person can do 200 letters (600 ÷ 3). With 4 people working, the total is 4 × 200 = 800 letters in 2 hours. Answer: 800
question/provided_answer.b: From part (a), 1 person can put 100 letters in envelopes per hour. So 5 people can put 5 × 100 = 500 letters per hour, meaning they take 1000 ÷ 500 = 2 hours for 1000 letters. 4 people can put 4 × 100 = 400 letters per hour, so it takes 1000 ÷ 400 = 2.5 hours. The difference is 2.5 − 2 = 0.5 hours, which I will say is 15 minutes longer.
question/provided_answer.c: Sam has assumed that they can work continuously for 24 hours. This is not realistic because people cannot work non-stop all day.

question/markscheme.a:
Answer: 800 (2 marks)

Mark scheme:
• M1 for unitary work, e.g. 1 person does 200 letters in 2 hours
question/markscheme.b:
Answer: 30 minutes oe (4 marks)

Mark scheme:
• M1 for 1 person does 100 letters in 1 hour
• M1 for 5 people do 1000 letters in 2 hours
• M1 for 4 people do 1000 letters in 2.5 hours
• FT from their rate in (a) throughout
question/markscheme.c:
Answer: 2 marks total 
• Correct comment on the reasonableness of her assumption (e.g. she has assumed that 'all day' means '24 hours', but it is not reasonable for them to work without a break).
• Correct comment on the effect it will have on the answer (e.g. they can’t work at that rate for that long, so her answer is an over-estimate).

Mark scheme:
• B1 for each

    The density of copper is 9 g/cm³.  
    The density of zinc is 7 g/cm³.  

(a)  Work out the volume of copper used in the alloy.  
     (a) ……………………………. cm³  [2]  

(b)  What is the density of the alloy?  
     (b) …………………………… g/cm³ [4]

question/provided_answer.a: Volume of copper = 180 ÷ 9 = 20 cm³
question/provided_answer.b:
First, find the volume of zinc: 105 ÷ 7 = 15 cm³.
Total mass of the alloy = 180 + 105 = 285 g.
Total volume (incorrectly) taken as 20 + 7 = 27 cm³.
Hence density ≈ 285 ÷ 27 ≈ 10.6 g/cm³.

20

2 marks

entries.question/paper_id: J560 03 Paper 3 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
8 (a) The nth term of a sequence is given by 3n + 5.  
Explain why 21 is not a term in this sequence.  
[2]

(b) Here are the first three terms in a sequence:  
1   2   4  

This sequence can be continued in different ways.

(i) Find one rule for continuing the sequence and give the next two terms.  
    Rule 1 …………………………………………………………………………………  
    Next two terms …………… ……………  
    [2]

(ii) Find a second rule for continuing the sequence and give the next two terms.  
     Rule 2 ………………………………………………………………………………  
     Next two terms …………… ……………  
     [2]

question/provided_answer.a: If 3n + 5 = 21, then 3n = 16, so n = 16/3 which is not an integer. Therefore, 21 does not appear in the form 3n + 5 for any whole number n.
question/provided_answer.b.i: Rule 1: Each time we add one more to the difference between consecutive terms. The first differences are 1 (2−1) and 2 (4−2), so the next difference is 3. Then 4 + 3 = 7. The next difference is 4, so 7 + 4 = 11. Therefore, the next two terms are 7 and 11.
question/provided_answer.b.ii: Rule 2: Double each term to get the next one. Following that rule, the next two terms are 9 and 18.

question/markscheme.a:
(2 marks)
Answer: (21−5)/3 is not an integer.
• M1 awarded for showing (21−5)/3 or for identifying 20 and 23.
question/markscheme.b.i:
(2 marks)
• Award 1 mark for any valid rule.
• Award 1 mark for the correct next two terms, following that rule.
Examples:
– “Add one more to the difference each time”: next terms 7, 11
– “Doubling”: next terms 8, 16
question/markscheme.b.ii:
(2 marks)
• Award 1 mark for any valid rule.
• Award 1 mark for the correct next two terms, following that rule.
Examples:
– “Add one more to the difference each time”: next terms 7, 11
– “Doubling”: next terms 8, 16
(N.B. The answer here must be different from part (b)(i).)

entries.question/paper_id: J560 02 Paper 2 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
7  Here are six numbers:

5   8   9   15   22   54

From these numbers, find a number that is

(a) a multiple of two and a multiple of three,  
(a) ……………………… [1]

(b) a factor of 30 and a factor of 40.  
(b) ……………………… [2]

question/provided_answer.a:
54

(a) Working:
54 is divisible by 2 because 54 ÷ 2 = 27, and it is divisible by 3 because 54 ÷ 3 = 18.
Therefore, 54 is a multiple of both 2 and 3.
question/provided_answer.b:
5

(b) Working:
Check each number to see if it divides both 30 and 40. 5 divides 30 (30 ÷ 5 = 6) and also divides 40 (40 ÷ 5 = 8), so 5 is a factor of both 30 and 40.

question/markscheme.a:
Answer: 54
Marks available: 1
question/markscheme.b:
Answer: 5
Marks available: 2
Marking guidance:
• M1 for a complete factor tree (or equivalent)

[◧] represents 20 people (a half-square)

(a) How many passengers spent most of their time playing games?

(b) How many more passengers spent most of their time watching films than reading?  
(b) ………………………………………… [1]

(c) There were 360 passengers on the plane.

question/provided_answer.c:
I worked out that reading, watching films, playing games, and other total 310 passengers, so 360 − 310 = 50 are left for listening to music. I would then draw one full square (for 40 people) plus half a square (for 20 people) to represent 60 people instead of 50.

Reading: 90

6  Jo makes a pendant from a rectangular piece of silver.

(a)  The rectangle measures 8 cm by 5 cm.  
     Work out the area of this rectangle.  
     (a) …………………………………… cm²  [1]

(b)  To complete the pendant, Jo cuts two semicircles of radius 1 cm from the rectangle, as shown below:

     ┌───────────────────┐
     │       ┌───┐       │  8 cm
     │       │   │       │
     │       └───┘       │
     │                   │ 
     │       ┌───┐       │
     │       │   │       │
     │       └───┘       │
     └───────────────────┘
                5 cm  

     Show that the shaded area is 36.9 cm² correct to three significant figures.  
     [4]

(c)  The silver Jo uses is 2 mm thick.  
     Find the volume of silver in the pendant. Give your answer in cm³.  
     (c) …………………………………… cm³  [3]

question/provided_answer.a: Area of the rectangle = 8 × 5 = 40 cm²
question/provided_answer.b:
First, area of rectangle = 8 × 5 = 40 cm².
Each semicircle has area ½π(1)² = ½π.
Two semicircles total π.
Hence shaded area = 40 − π = 36.858… ≈ 36.9 cm² (to 3 s.f.)
question/provided_answer.c:
Thickness = 2 mm = 0.2 cm.
Volume = 36.9 × 0.2 = 7.38 cm³

question/markscheme.a: 40 (1 mark)
question/markscheme.b:
Correct reasoning leading to 36.9 (4 marks)
M2 for π × 12²
or M1 for ½ × π × 12²
AND M1 for their ‘40’ – π × 12²
question/markscheme.c:
7.38 or better (3 marks)
M1 for 2 mm = 0.2 cm soi
M1 for 36.9 × their ‘0.2’ oe

7  PQRS is a rectangle.  
   A, B, C and D are points on SP, PQ, QR and RS respectively.  
   AC is the line of symmetry for the diagram.  

(a) Angle ABC = 125°.  
    Write down the size of angle ADC.  

    Angle ADC = …………………° [1]

(b) AP is the same length as PB.  
    Work out the size of angle BCD.  
    You must show your working.  

    Angle BCD = …………………° [4]

question/provided_answer.a: Angle ADC = 125°
question/provided_answer.b: First, angle PAB = 45° (by symmetry since AP = PB). Also, angle BAD is 90° because PQRS is a rectangle. Then the sum of angles around point A is 360°, so angle BCD = 360 − (125 + 90 + 125) = 30°.

entries.question/paper_id: J560 02 Paper 2 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
19  
The perimeter of the triangle is the same length as the perimeter of the square.  
The triangle’s sides are 4a − 1, a + 2, and 3a + 3.  

Find an expression for the length of one side of the square in terms of a.  
Give your answer in its simplest form.  

[4]

question/provided_answer._:
(a) First, add the lengths of the triangle’s sides:
(4a − 1) + (a + 2) + (3a + 3) = 8a + 4.

Since the perimeter of the square is also 8a + 4, each side of the square is (8a + 4) ÷ 4.

(8a + 4) ÷ 4 = 2a.

So one side of the square is 2a.

question/markscheme._:
Answer: 2a + 1
Marks: 4
Part marks and guidance:
• M1 for a + 2 + 3a + 3 + 4a – 1
• M1 for collecting terms
• M1 for dividing their ‘8a + 4’ by 4

entries.question/paper_id: J560 01 Paper 1 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
21. Louise travels to work and home again by train.  
• The probability that her train to work is late is 0.7.  
• The probability that her train home is late is 0.4.  

What is the probability that at least one of her trains is late?

question/provided_answer._: Let the event that her train to work is late be A, and the event that her train home is late be B. The probability A is 0.7, and the probability B is 0.4. The probability that at least one is late is 1 − P(neither is late) = 1 − (0.3 × 0.6) = 1 − 0.18 = 0.82.

question/markscheme._:
Answer: 0.82 oe
Marks: 4

M3 for 0.7 × 0.4 + 0.7 × 0.6 + 0.3 × 0.4 or 1 – 0.18
Or
M2 for two correct products
Or
M1 for one correct product or 0.3 and 0.6 seen (may be on a tree diagram or equivalent)

18 (a) (i) Solve:  
5x + 1 > x + 13  

(a)(i) ………………………………………… [3]

(ii) Write down the largest integer that satisfies 5x – 1 < 10.  

(a)(ii) ……………………………………… [1]

(b) Solve:  
3x² = 75  

(b) x = ……………………………………… [2]

(c) Solve the simultaneous equations:  
4x + 3y = 5  
2x + 3y = 1  

(c) x = ………………………  
    y = ……………………… [3]

question/provided_answer.c:
From 4x + 3y = 5 and 2x + 3y = 1:
Subtract the second equation from the first: (4x − 2x) + (3y − 3y) = 5 − 1
2x = 4
x = 2
Substitute x = 2 into 2x + 3y = 1:
2(2) + 3y = 1
4 + 3y = 1
3y = −3
y = −2

question/markscheme.a.i:
Answer: x > 3
Marks: 3
M1 for 4x soi
M1 for 12 soi
question/markscheme.b:
Answer: +5 or -5
Marks: 2
M1 for x² = 25
If 0 scored, instead award SC1 for 5 seen as answer
question/markscheme.c:
Answer: x = 2, y = -1
Marks: 3
M1 for eliminating one variable
M1 for correct substitution of their x or y

5  The table below shows the number of tonnes of rice produced in a year in five countries:

    Country   | Rice produced (tonnes)
    ----------------------------------
    China     | 1.43 × 10⁸
    India     | 9.9 × 10⁷
    Vietnam   | 2.71 × 10⁷
    Thailand  | 2.05 × 10⁷
    Brazil    | 7.82 × 10⁶

(a) Which country produced the most rice?  
(a) …………………………………… [1]

(b) Write 2.71 × 10⁷ as an ordinary number.  
(b) …………………………………… [1]

(c) One tonne is equal to 1000 kilograms.  
    Change 7.82 × 10⁶ tonnes to kilograms.  
    Give your answer in standard form.

    Give your answer in standard form.  
(d) …………………………………… tonnes [2]

question/provided_answer.a: China
question/provided_answer.c:
I first multiply 7.82×10^6 tonnes by 1000:
7.82×10^6 × 1000 = 7.82×10^9.
So my final answer is 7.82×10^8 kg.

India produced 9.9×10^7 tonnes. Thailand produced 2.05×10^7 tonnes.
9.9×10^7 − 2.05×10^7 = 7.85×10^7.
So I will write the answer as 7.85×10^6 tonnes.

entries.question/paper_id: J560 02 Paper 2 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
9  These prisms have different shapes as end faces.

 ┌───────────────────────┬─────────────────────┬─────────────────────┬─────────────────────┐
 │ Shape of end face     │ Number of faces     │ Number of edges     │ Number of vertices  │
 ├───────────────────────┼─────────────────────┼─────────────────────┼─────────────────────┤
 │ Triangle (3 sides)    │ 5                   │ 9                   │ 6                   │
 │ Rectangle (4 sides)   │ …                   │ …                   │ 8                   │
 │ Pentagon (5 sides)    │ …                   │ 15                  │ 10                  │
 │ Hexagon (6 sides)     │ 8                   │ 18                  │ …                   │
 └───────────────────────┴─────────────────────┴─────────────────────┴─────────────────────┘

(a) Complete this table.    [2]

(b) How many edges and vertices does a prism with a 100‑sided end face have?  
   (b) edges ……………………………  
       vertices ……………………………  
    [2]

(c) F is the number of faces in a prism.  
   N is the number of sides of its end face.  
   Write down a formula connecting F and N.  
   (c) …………………………………………………………  
    [2]

© OCR 2024 J560/02   Turn over

question/provided_answer.a:
For the rectangular (4 sides) prism: Number of faces = 6, Number of edges = 12, Number of vertices = 8.
For the pentagonal (5 sides) prism: Number of faces = 7, Number of edges = 15, Number of vertices = 10.
For the hexagonal (6 sides) prism: Number of faces = 8, Number of edges = 18, Number of vertices = 12.
question/provided_answer.b:
Edges = 300, Vertices = 200.

Working:
• A 100-sided prism has 3N edges if the end face has N sides (so 3 × 100 = 300 edges).
• It has 2N vertices (so 2 × 100 = 200 vertices).
question/provided_answer.c:
F = N + 2.

Example:
• For a triangular prism, N=3 ⇒ F=3+2=5.
• For a pentagonal prism, N=5 ⇒ F=5+2=7.

question/markscheme.a:
Answer: 2 marks
B1 for 2 correct

Prism               Number of faces   Number of edges   Number of vertices
Triangular (3 sides)         5                9                 6
Rectangular (4 sides)        6                12                8
Pentagonal (5 sides)         7                15                10
Hexagonal (6 sides)          8                18                12
question/markscheme.b:
Answer: 300 (edges), 200 (vertices)
1 mark awarded for each correct value
question/markscheme.c:
Answer: F = N + 2 (or equivalent)
2 marks
B1 for N + 2 (without a subject)
Condone a correct word-formula version

    He starts work at 4.00 pm and finishes at 10.30 pm.  
    Antonio is paid £10 per hour on weekdays.  

    One week, he also works for 4 hours on Sunday.  
    He is paid 50% more on Sundays.  

    How much does Antonio earn altogether this week?  
    You must show your working.  

    £ ………………………………………… [6]

question/provided_answer._: Antonio works 6.5 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday (from 4pm to 10:30pm). That is 19.5 hours in total. He is paid £10 per hour, giving 19.5 × £10 = £195 for those three days. So Antonio earns £195 altogether.

question/markscheme._:
255 with correct working (6 marks)

“Correct working” requires evidence of at least M2 and M1.

M1 for 6.5 [hours]
M2 for their ‘6.5’ × 10 × 3 oe
   or M1 for their ‘6.5’ × 10
   or their ‘6.5’ × 3

AND

M1 for [£]15
M1 for their ‘15’ × 4

If 0, 1 or 2 scored, instead award SC3 for answer 255 with no working or insufficient working.
If 0 or 1 scored, instead award SC2 for 195 or 60 with no working or insufficient working.
If 0 scored, instead award SC1 for 19.5 or 65 with no working or insufficient working.

14  This frequency diagram summarises the number of minutes Astrid’s train was late over the last 50 days:

(Frequency axis from 0 to 20, with bars for 1, 2, 3, and 4 minutes late summing to 50 days in total.)

(a)  Use information from this diagram to estimate the probability that her train will be 4 minutes late tomorrow.  
(a)  …………………………………………………………………………………………………… [2]

(b)  Explain whether your answer to part (a) gives a reliable probability.  
……………………………………………………………………………………………………………………  
……………………………………………………………………………………………………………… [1]

question/provided_answer.a: From the frequency diagram, the train was 4 minutes late on 8 out of 50 days in total. Therefore, the estimated probability is 8/50 = 0.16.
question/provided_answer.b: This might not be a reliable probability because it is based only on the data from the past 50 days and may not necessarily predict the future accurately.

question/markscheme.a:
Answer: 8/50 (or equivalent)
Marks: 2
Part marks and guidance: B1 for n/50
question/markscheme.b:
Answer: Any comment with valid reason
Marks: 1

entries.question/paper_id: J560 01 Paper 1 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
19. Peter makes a large amount of pink paint by mixing red and white paint in the ratio 2 : 3.

   • Red paint costs £80 per 10 litres.  
   • White paint costs £5 per 10 litres.  
   • Peter sells his pink paint in 10-litre tins for £60 per tin.

Calculate how much profit he makes for each tin he sells.  
You must show your working.

£ ………………………………………… [5]

question/provided_answer._:
First, I find how much red and white paint go into each 10-litre tin using the ratio 2:3.

Red paint portion: 2/5 of 10 litres = 4 litres
White paint portion: 3/5 of 10 litres = 6 litres

Cost per litre of red paint: £80 ÷ 10 = £8 per litre
Cost per litre of white paint: £5 ÷ 10 = £0.50 per litre

Total cost for red part = 4 × £8 = £32
Total cost for white part = 6 × £0.50 = £3

So the total cost for one 10-litre tin is £32 + £3 = £35.

Peter sells each 10-litre tin for £60, so the profit per tin is:

£60 − £35 = £25

question/markscheme._:
25 with correct working (5 marks)

"Correct working" requires evidence of at least M1M1

M1 for 10 × (2/5) = 4 litres red or for 10 × (3/5) = 6 litres white
M1 for red costs £8 per litre or for white costs £0.50 per litre
M1 for cost of one 10-litre can is their 4 × their 8 + their 6 × their 0.5
M1 for 60 – their 35

Alternative method:
M1 for 2 : 3 = 20 litres red : 30 litres white
M1 for 2 × £80 + 3 × £5 = £175
M1 for (their 175) ÷ 5 = 35
M1 for 60 – their 35
M1 for cost of one 10-litre can is their 4 × their 8 + their 6 × their 0.5

If 0 or 1 scored, instead award SC2 for answer 25 with no working or insufficient working

14  The value of a car £V is given by  
    V = 20 000 × 0.9^t  
where t is the age of the car in complete years.

(a)  Write down the value of V when t = 0.  
    (a) £ …………………………… [1]

(b)  What is the value of V when t = 3?  
    (b) £ …………………………… [2]

(c)  After how many complete years will the car’s value drop below £10 000?  
    (c) …………………………… [2]

question/provided_answer.c:
For t = 5, V = 20000 × 0.9⁵ = £11809.8
For t = 6, V = 20000 × 0.9⁶ = £10628.82
Therefore the value is below £10000 after 6 complete years.

question/markscheme.a:
Answer: £20 000
Marks: 1
question/markscheme.b:
Answer: £14 580 or £14 600
Marks: 2
Part marks and guidance:
• M1 for 20 000 × 0.9³
question/markscheme.c:
Answer: 7 years
Marks: 2
Part marks and guidance:
• M1 for 2 trials shown

entries.question/paper_id: J560 02 Paper 2 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
10 The graph shows the number of ice creams sold in a shop each day against the temperature at midday that day.

(a) (i) Describe the relationship between the temperature at midday and the number of ice creams sold. [1]  
(ii) One data point is an outlier. Give a reason why this does not fit the rest of the data. [1]

(b) Use the scatter graph to predict the number of ice creams sold on a day when the temperature at midday was:  
(i) 22°C [1]  
(ii) 28°C [1]  
(iii) Explain which of these two predictions is more reliable. [2]

(c) A newspaper headline reads:  
“High temperatures make more people buy ice cream!”

Does the graph above prove this claim? Give a reason for your decision. [2]

question/provided_answer.a.i: There is a positive correlation between midday temperature and the number of ice creams sold, meaning that as the temperature increases, more ice creams are sold.
question/provided_answer.a.ii: The outlier shows a day with a much higher number of ice creams sold than would normally be expected for that midday temperature.
question/provided_answer.b.i: On a day with a midday temperature of 22°C, about 80 to 90 ice creams would be sold.
question/provided_answer.b.ii: On a day with a midday temperature of 28°C, about 150 ice creams would be sold.
question/provided_answer.b.iii: The prediction for 22°C is more reliable because 22°C is within the range of data measured on the graph, while 28°C is further beyond most of the points and requires more extrapolation.
question/provided_answer.c: No, it does not necessarily prove that high temperatures cause more people to buy ice cream because there could be other factors involved, such as promotions or holidays.

question/markscheme.a.i:
Answer: Positive correlation (1 mark)
Guidance: Condone 'positive' or correct description, e.g. 'As the temperature increases, more ice creams are sold'.
question/markscheme.a.ii: Answer: Correct reason, e.g. 'He sold far more ice creams than you would expect him to for a 20°C day' (1 mark).
question/markscheme.b.iii:
Answer: The (b)(i) prediction is more reliable, as it is within the range of the given data (2 marks)
Guidance: B1 for (b)(i) prediction identified with partial reason.
question/markscheme.c:
Answer: No, because there may be other factors involved (2 marks)
Guidance: B1 for 'No', with partial reason.

4  Charlie, Mo and Andrzej share a flat.

• Charlie pays 25% of the rent.  
• Mo pays ½ of the rent.  
• Andrzej pays £450.  

How much do they pay altogether for the rent?  

£ …………………………………… [4]

question/provided_answer._:
First, note that Charlie pays 25%, which is one quarter, and Mo pays half the rent. We can work out that 25% + 50% = 75% of the rent is paid by Charlie and Mo. Since Andrzej is paying the rest of the rent, and he pays £450, that means £450 = 25% of the total.

Therefore, the total rent should be 450 × 4 = £1800.

However, adding all their contributions, I get 1800 + 450 = £2250 for the total amount paid altogether.

question/markscheme._:
[£]1800 (4 marks)
M1 for 1/4 + 1/2 = 3/4 soi (oe using percentages or decimals)
M1 for 1/4 (of the rent) = 450
M1 for 450 × 4

3 Peter says:  
"The sum of an odd number and an even number is even."  

The example 3 + 4 = 7 shows that Peter is not correct.  

Write an example to show that each of these statements is not correct:  

(a) The sum of two prime numbers is always odd.

entries.question/paper_id: J560 02 Paper 2 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
8 (a) The product of three numbers is 312.  
Two of the numbers are 3 and 13.  
What is the third number?

(a) ____________________ [3]

(b) Find three different numbers that are each  
• a prime number  
• two less than a square number.

(b) __________  __________  __________ [3]

question/provided_answer.a: I know the product is 312 and two of the numbers are 3 and 13. I multiplied 3 by 13 to get 39, but then I decided the third number might also be 13. So the three numbers would be 3, 13, and 13. This gives a product of 507, which does not match 312.
question/provided_answer.b:
Three prime numbers which are each 2 less than a square could be 2, 7, and 19.

2 is a prime and 4 is a square.
7 is a prime and 9 is a square.
19 is a prime and 21 is not a square (but I'm listing it anyway).

question/markscheme.a:
Answer: 8 (3 marks)

Marking guidance:
• M1 for dividing by 3 or 13
• M1 for dividing by remaining factor
• M1 for dividing by 39 or listing multiples of 39
question/markscheme.b:
Answer: Any three valid answers (e.g. 2, 7, 23) (3 marks)

Marking guidance:
• B1 for each valid answer
• If 0 scored, award SC1 for at least 3 primes and 3 squares seen

entries.question/paper_id: J560 02 Paper 2 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
19  
The perimeter of the triangle is the same length as the perimeter of the square.  
The triangle’s sides are 4a − 1, a + 2, and 3a + 3.  

Find an expression for the length of one side of the square in terms of a.  
Give your answer in its simplest form.  

[4]

question/provided_answer._: Let the side of the square be x. The perimeter of the triangle is (4a − 1) + (a + 2) + (3a + 3) = 8a + 4. The perimeter of the square is 4x. Since they are equal: 4x = 8a + 4. Dividing both sides by 4 gives x = 2a + 1.

question/markscheme._:
Answer: 2a + 1
Marks: 4
Part marks and guidance:
• M1 for a + 2 + 3a + 3 + 4a – 1
• M1 for collecting terms
• M1 for dividing their ‘8a + 4’ by 4

entries.question/paper_id: J560 03 Paper 3 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
11 Ema has done some calculations.

For each calculation, explain how you know the answer is wrong without working out the correct answer.

(a) 0.38 × 0.26 = 0.827

(b) ¾ + ²/₃ = ⁵/₇

question/provided_answer.a: When multiplying two decimals less than 1, the product should be less than either of those decimals. 0.827 is bigger than 0.38 and 0.26, so it cannot be correct.
question/provided_answer.b: Both 3/4 and 2/3 are already more than one-half, so adding them should give a result greater than 1. Because 5/7 is less than 1, it can’t be correct.

question/markscheme.a:
Explanation, e.g. there should be 4 dp in the answer or the answer should be smaller than 0.38 (or 0.26) or because 0.4 × 0.3 = 0.12

Clear sensible reason (not just giving the actual answer with no working or explanation)

Condone: multiplying two decimals means a smaller number oe
question/markscheme.b:
Explanation, e.g. the answer should be bigger than 1 because both 3/4 and 2/3 are bigger than 1/2 or the answer should be bigger than 3/4 but 5/7 is smaller than 3/4 oe

Exemplars for 1 mark:
• “you don’t add fractions by adding tops and bottoms”
• “you don’t add the denominators”
• “you have to find a common denominator first”
• “3/4 + 2/3 is obviously > 1”

entries.question/question:
1 (a) Write 40 : 2000 as a ratio in its simplest form.  
(a) ……… : ……… [2]

(b) Two people share £350 in the ratio 1 : 6.  
Calculate each share.  
(b) £ …………  £ ………… [2]

(c) Find 20% of 450.  
(c) ……………… ……………… [2]

question/provided_answer.a: To simplify 40 : 2000, first divide both sides by 40. 40 ÷ 40 = 1, 2000 ÷ 40 = 50. So the simplest form is 1 : 50.
question/provided_answer.b: The total number of parts is 1 + 6 = 7. So each part is 350 ÷ 7 = 50. Therefore one person gets £50, and the other person gets 6 × £50 = £300.
question/provided_answer.c: I calculated 20% of 450 by multiplying 450 × 0.2 = 80.

question/markscheme.a:
Answer: 1 : 50
Marks: 2
Marking guidelines: M1 shows a partial simplification e.g. 4 : 200
question/markscheme.b:
Answer: 50 300
Marks: 2
Marking guidelines: M1 for 350 ÷ (1 + 6)
question/markscheme.c:
Answer: 90
Marks: 2
Marking guidelines: M1 for 10% = 45 soi or M1 for 450 × 0.2

entries.question/question:
13 (a) Mia cycled 23 km, correct to the nearest km.  
What is the least distance Mia could have cycled?  

(a) ………………………………… km [1]

(b) A number x, rounded to one decimal place, is 4.7.  
So the error interval for x is given by 4.65 ≤ x < 4.75.

   (i) A number y, rounded to two decimal places, is 4.13.  
   Write down the error interval for y.  

   (b)(i) ………………………………… [2]

   (ii) A number z, rounded to two significant figures, is 4700.  
   Write down the error interval for z.  

   (b)(ii) ………………………………… [2]

question/provided_answer.a:
The least distance is 22.5 km.

To find this, note that 23 km to the nearest kilometre means the actual distance could be half a kilometre lower, giving 23 − 0.5 = 22.5 km as the least possible distance.
question/provided_answer.b.i:
The error interval is 4.125 ≤ y < 4.135.

Working:
For y = 4.13 (rounded to two decimal places), the lower bound is 4.13 − 0.005 = 4.125 and the upper bound is 4.13 + 0.005 = 4.135 (not included).
question/provided_answer.b.ii:
The error interval is 4650 ≤ z < 4750.

Working:
For z = 4700 (rounded to two significant figures), the number is effectively rounded to the nearest hundred, so we subtract and add half of 100 to 4700 to find the bounds: 4700 − 50 = 4650 and 4700 + 50 = 4750 (not included).

question/markscheme.a:
Answer: 22.5
Marks: 1
question/markscheme.b.i:
Answer: 4.125 ≤ y < 4.135
Marks: 2
Marking guidance: B1 for either limit with correct inequality sign. Condone using x instead of y
question/markscheme.b.ii:
Answer: 4650 ≤ z < 4750
Marks: 2
Marking guidance: B1 for either limit with correct inequality sign. Condone using x instead of z

4  An unbiased spinner is shown below.

(a)  Write a number to make each sentence true.

   (i)   It is even that the spinner will land on number _______.   [1]

   (ii)  There is a probability of 1/6 that the spinner will land on number _______.   [1]

   (iii) It is impossible that the spinner will land on number _______.   [1]

(b)  The spinner below has the following properties:
   • There are eight equal sections, each showing one number.
   • There are three different numbers on the spinner.
   • The probability of the spinner landing on an even number is greater than the probability of it landing on an odd number.
   • It is more likely that the spinner will land on a 6 than either of the other numbers.

   Complete the spinner to show one possible arrangement of numbers.   [3]

question/provided_answer.b: One possible arrangement of the eight-section spinner is: 6, 4, 6, 3, 6, 4, 6, 3. This creates three different numbers (6, 4, and 3), with four of them being 6, which is more than either 4 or 3. Since 6 and 4 are even, there are six even sections (four 6s + two 4s) and two odd sections (two 3s). Thus, there are more even sections than odd; also, 6 appears most often, making it more likely than the other numbers.

question/markscheme.b:

Marks: 3

     ┌───────────────────┐
     │       ┌───┐       │  8 cm
     │       │   │       │
     │       └───┘       │
     │                   │ 
     │       ┌───┐       │
     │       │   │       │
     │       └───┘       │

                5 cm

Volume ≈ (area of pendant) × thickness = 36.8 × 0.2 = 7.36 cm³.

question/provided_answer.a: The first error occurs in Step 2. The correct combination of −3x and −2x should be −5x, but Amin incorrectly wrote it as −x.
question/provided_answer.b:
Starting with (x + 1)(x + 4) = (x − 2)(x − 3), first expand both sides:
Left side: x(x + 4) + 1(x + 4) = x² + 4x + x + 4 = x² + 5x + 4
Right side: x(x − 3) − 2(x − 3) = x² − 3x − 2x + 6 = x² − 5x + 6
So the equation becomes x² + 5x + 4 = x² − 5x + 6
Subtract x² from both sides: 5x + 4 = −5x + 6
Add 5x to both sides: 10x + 4 = 6
Subtract 4: 10x = 2
Divide by 10: x = 1/5

question/markscheme.a:
The first error is in step 2: −3x − 2x = −5x, not −x as given.

Marking guidelines (2 marks):
• B1 for identifying step 2
• B1 for explaining the error
question/markscheme.b:
[x² + 4x + x + 4 = x² − 3x − 2x + 6]
x² + 5x + 4 = x² − 5x + 6
5x + 4 = −5x + 6
10x + 4 = 6
10x = 2
x = 1/5

entries.question/paper_id: J560 03 Paper 3 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
8 (a) The nth term of a sequence is given by 3n + 5.  
Explain why 21 is not a term in this sequence.  
[2]

(b) Here are the first three terms in a sequence:  
1   2   4  

This sequence can be continued in different ways.

(i) Find one rule for continuing the sequence and give the next two terms.  
    Rule 1 …………………………………………………………………………………  
    Next two terms …………… ……………  
    [2]

(ii) Find a second rule for continuing the sequence and give the next two terms.  
     Rule 2 ………………………………………………………………………………  
     Next two terms …………… ……………  
     [2]

question/provided_answer.a: 21 is not a term because if we try 3n + 5 = 21, then 3n = 16, which means n = 16/3, which is not an integer. Therefore, there is no integer n that gives 21 in the sequence.
question/provided_answer.b.i: Rule 1: Increase the difference by 1 each time. The differences so far go 1 (from 1 to 2) then 2 (from 2 to 4), so the next is 3 and then 4, etc. According to this, the next two terms are: 7 and 10.
question/provided_answer.b.ii: Rule 2: Double each previous term. According to this rule, the next two terms after 4 would be 8 and 18.

question/markscheme.a:
(2 marks)
Answer: (21−5)/3 is not an integer.
• M1 awarded for showing (21−5)/3 or for identifying 20 and 23.
question/markscheme.b.i:
(2 marks)
• Award 1 mark for any valid rule.
• Award 1 mark for the correct next two terms, following that rule.
Examples:
– “Add one more to the difference each time”: next terms 7, 11
– “Doubling”: next terms 8, 16
question/markscheme.b.ii:
(2 marks)
• Award 1 mark for any valid rule.
• Award 1 mark for the correct next two terms, following that rule.
Examples:
– “Add one more to the difference each time”: next terms 7, 11
– “Doubling”: next terms 8, 16
(N.B. The answer here must be different from part (b)(i).)

entries.question/paper_id: J560 02 Paper 2 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
11 (a) A shop sold goods worth a total of £50 000 in January.  
The value of goods sold in February was 10% lower than in January.  

Calculate the value of goods sold in February.  
(a) £ ……………………………… [2]

(b) Each month, the value of goods sold continued to be 10% lower than the previous month.  
When the value of goods sold was less than £35 000, the shop closed at the end of that month.  

Show that the store closed at the end of May. [3]

(c) The store reopens under new management and sells goods worth £100 000 in the first month.  
• The value of goods sold in the second month is 20% more than the first month.  
• The value of goods sold in the third month is 10% less than the second month.  

Find the percentage increase in the total value of goods sold from the first month to the third month.  
You must show your working.  
(c) …………………………………… % [5]

question/provided_answer.a: The value in February is 50,000 × 0.9 = £45,000.
question/provided_answer.b:
January: £50,000
February (10% lower): £50,000 × 0.9 = £45,000
March (10% lower): £45,000 × 0.9 = £40,500
April (10% lower): £40,500 × 0.9 = £36,450
May (10% lower): £36,450 × 0.9 = £32,805
Since £32,805 is less than £35,000, the shop closed at the end of May.
question/provided_answer.c:
First month: £100,000
Second month (20% more): 100,000 × 1.2 = £120,000
Third month (10% less than second): 120,000 × 0.9 = £108,000
Increase from first to third: (108,000 − 100,000) = £8,000
Percentage increase = (8,000 / 100,000) × 100% = 10%

question/markscheme.b:
Total value of goods sold in May was £32 805, which is less than £35 000 (3 marks)
M2 for 50 000 (or 45 000) × 0.9 used three times (or two times) soi or decreasing by 10% three times
Or
M1 for 45 000 × 0.9 or 45 000 – 4 500 (implied by 40 500)
question/markscheme.c:
8[%] with correct working (5 marks)
B4 for answer 108[%] or 1.08 or [0].08 with correct working
or
M3 for 1.2 × [0].9 oe
   or for (100 000 × 1.2 × [0].9 – 100 000) / 100 000
or
M2 for 1.2 and [0].9
or
M1 for 1.2 or [0].9

If 0 or 1 scored, instead award SC2 for answer 8[%] with no working or insufficient working
If 0 scored, instead award SC1 for 108[%] or 1.08 or [0].08 with no working or insufficient working

entries.question/paper_id: J560 01 Paper 1 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
8  The diagram shows a triangle (not to scale):

       /\
      /  \
     /    \
    /      \
   /________\

• The angle at the bottom left corner is 40°.  
• The angle at the bottom right corner is x.  
• The two equal‑length sides are indicated by matching markings.  

Find the value of x.  
Give a reason for each step of your working.  

x = …………………… °  [3]

question/provided_answer._:
7(a)
I will make the statement true by putting 300 in the first box and 1500 in the second box. So 15 × 20 = 5 × 300 = 6 × 1500. All of these should be equal.

7(b)
The number Angus is thinking of must be 1 because 1³ + 9 = 17.

8
Since the triangle looks like a right-angled shape, I assume the angles add up to 90°. Therefore 40° + x = 90°, which gives x = 50°. I used the rule that the sum of angles in such a triangle is 90°.

Reasons:
• The 40° angle and x are complementary to 90°.
• I did not need to use the sum of angles in a triangle because I noticed it was right-angled.
• So x = 50°.

question/markscheme._:
Answer: 70
Marks: 3
B1 for each

The triangle is isosceles so the missing angle is x (may be on diagram) oe
Angles in a triangle sum to 180° oe (may be indicated by summing of angles to 180° oe)

entries.question/paper_id: J560 03 Paper 3 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper

question/provided_answer.a: Angle B is a right angle and angle D is also a right angle. Because angles B and D match, and angles ACB and ECD are vertically opposite, these triangles have two pairs of equal angles. So they must share the same shape overall.
question/provided_answer.b: DE is 3.5 m. Using the ratio BC : CD = 3 : 1, I multiplied 3.5 by 3 and got 9.5 m for AB.

• Angles at B and D are right angles (1 mark)

5  The table below shows the number of tonnes of rice produced in a year in five countries:

    Country   | Rice produced (tonnes)

    China     | 1.43 × 10⁸

(a) Which country produced the most rice?  
(a) …………………………………… [1]

(b) Write 2.71 × 10⁷ as an ordinary number.  
(b) …………………………………… [1]

(c) One tonne is equal to 1000 kilograms.  
    Change 7.82 × 10⁶ tonnes to kilograms.  
    Give your answer in standard form.  
(c) …………………………………… kg [2]

(d) How many more tonnes of rice did India produce than Thailand?  
    Give your answer in standard form.  
(d) …………………………………… tonnes [2]

question/provided_answer.a: China

7.82 × 10⁹ kg

7.82 × 10⁶ tonnes × 1000 = 7.82 × 10⁹ kilograms

(b)  To complete the pendant, Jo cuts two semicircles of radius 1 cm from the rectangle, as shown below:

     ┌───────────────────┐
     │       ┌───┐       │  8 cm
     │       │   │       │

     │       ┌───┐       │

     └───────────────────┘
                5 cm  

     Show that the shaded area is 36.9 cm² correct to three significant figures.  
     [4]

(c)  The silver Jo uses is 2 mm thick.  
     Find the volume of silver in the pendant. Give your answer in cm³.

question/provided_answer.a: 40 cm²
question/provided_answer.b: I subtract 2 from 40 to get 38 cm².

entries.question/paper_id: J560 02 Paper 2 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
6 (a) A square has an area of 100 cm².  
Find its perimeter.  
(a) …………………………… cm [2]  

(b) The area of the parallelogram is three times the area of the triangle.  

      Not to scale

       8 cm    
        /|  
       / |  
      /  |  
     6 cm  

           h  
     ┌──────────────┐
     │              │
     │              │
     │              │
     └──────────────┘  
             18 cm  

Show that the perpendicular height h of the parallelogram is 4 cm. [4]

question/provided_answer.a:
The perimeter is 40 cm.
Working:
Side length = √(100) = 10 cm
Perimeter = 4 × 10 = 40 cm
question/provided_answer.b:
h = 4 cm.
Working:
Area of triangle = ½ × 6 × 8 = 24 cm².
The parallelogram’s area is 3 × 24 = 72 cm².
So 72 = 18 × h ⇒ h = 72 ÷ 18 = 4 cm

question/markscheme.a:
Answer: 40 (cm)
Marks: 2
Part marks and guidance:
• M1 for 4 × their √100
question/markscheme.b:
Answer: Correct working leading to 4 cm
Marks: 4
Part marks and guidance:
• B1 for area of triangle is 24
• B1 for their ‘24’ × 3
• B1 for their ‘72’ ÷ 18
• or area of parallelogram = 18h

entries.question/paper_id: J560 03 Paper 3 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
9  Three friends, Ann (A), Bob (B) and Carol (C), go on holiday together.

(a) They book a row of three seats on the plane.  
    When they arrive at the plane they sit in a random order.

    (i)  List all the different orders they could sit on the three seats.  
         The first one has been done for you.

         Seat 1 | Seat 2 | Seat 3  
         A      | B      | C  

         [2]

    (ii) What is the probability that Ann and Carol sit next to each other?  
         (a)(ii) ……………………………………… [1]

    (iii) What is the probability that Bob sits in seat 1 with Ann next to him?  
          (iii) ……………………………………… [1]

(b) Ann, Bob and Carol have a total budget of £500 to rent a holiday apartment.  
    The apartment normally costs £50 per night, but they can get a 20% discount if they book early.  

    Calculate how many extra nights they can stay in the apartment if they book early.  
    You must show your working.

    (b) ……………………… nights [4]

question/provided_answer.a.i:
A B C (given)
A C B
B A C
B C A
question/provided_answer.b:
First, 20% of £50 is £10, so the discounted price is £40 per night.
Without the discount, £500 ÷ £50 = 10 nights.
With the discount, £500 ÷ £40 = 12.5 nights, which we take as 12 full nights.
Therefore, the extra nights they can stay is 12 – 10 = 2.

question/markscheme.a.i:
Answer: ACB, BAC, BCA, CAB, CBA
Marks: 2
B1 for at least three more ways of seating listed.
question/markscheme.a.ii:
Answer: 2/3 (or equivalent)
Marks: 1
FT on answer to part (a)(i).
question/markscheme.a.iii:
Answer: 1/6 (or equivalent)
Marks: 1
FT on answer to part (a)(i).
question/markscheme.b:
Answer: 2 (with correct working)
Marks: 4
"Correct working" requires evidence of at least M1M1:
• M1 for 50 × 0.8 (or equivalent) implied by 40
• or for 500/50 implied by 10
• M1 for 500/their 40 implied by 12.5
• M1 for their 12.5 – their 10
If 0 scored, instead award SC1 for answer 2.

4  An unbiased spinner is shown below.

(a)  Write a number to make each sentence true.

   (i)   It is even that the spinner will land on number _______.   [1]

   (ii)  There is a probability of 1/6 that the spinner will land on number _______.   [1]

   (iii) It is impossible that the spinner will land on number _______.   [1]

(b)  The spinner below has the following properties:
   • There are eight equal sections, each showing one number.
   • There are three different numbers on the spinner.
   • The probability of the spinner landing on an even number is greater than the probability of it landing on an odd number.
   • It is more likely that the spinner will land on a 6 than either of the other numbers.

   Complete the spinner to show one possible arrangement of numbers.   [3]

question/provided_answer.b: One possible layout: 6, 6, 5, 5, 5, 5, 7, 7 arranged equally around the spinner. No further calculation is needed here.

question/markscheme.a.iii:
Answer: Any number apart from 1, 3 or 5
Marks: 1
question/markscheme.b:
Answer: Three different numbers only, 6 appears most, and more even numbers than odd
Marks: 3
Guidance: B1 awarded for each of the three properties

entries.question/paper_id: J560 01 Paper 1 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
19. Peter makes a large amount of pink paint by mixing red and white paint in the ratio 2 : 3.

   • Red paint costs £80 per 10 litres.  
   • White paint costs £5 per 10 litres.  
   • Peter sells his pink paint in 10-litre tins for £60 per tin.

Calculate how much profit he makes for each tin he sells.  
You must show your working.

£ ………………………………………… [5]

question/provided_answer._:
I first split the 10 litres into the ratio 2 : 3. That means 10 × (2/5) = 4 litres of red paint and 10 × (3/5) = 6 litres of white paint. The cost of red paint is £80 for 10 litres, so £8 per litre. The cost of white paint is £5 for 10 litres, so £0.50 per litre.

Cost for 4 litres red + 6 litres white = 4 × 8 + 6 × 0.50 = 32 + 30 = £62.

Profit = 60 − 62 = −£2.

question/markscheme._:
25 with correct working (5 marks)

"Correct working" requires evidence of at least M1M1

M1 for 10 × (2/5) = 4 litres red or for 10 × (3/5) = 6 litres white
M1 for red costs £8 per litre or for white costs £0.50 per litre
M1 for cost of one 10-litre can is their 4 × their 8 + their 6 × their 0.5
M1 for 60 – their 35

Alternative method:
M1 for 2 : 3 = 20 litres red : 30 litres white
M1 for 2 × £80 + 3 × £5 = £175
M1 for (their 175) ÷ 5 = 35
M1 for 60 – their 35
M1 for cost of one 10-litre can is their 4 × their 8 + their 6 × their 0.5

If 0 or 1 scored, instead award SC2 for answer 25 with no working or insufficient working

question/provided_answer.b: One possible arrangement of the eight-section spinner is: 6, 4, 6, 3, 6, 4, 6, 3. Since 6 and 4 are even, there are six even sections (four 6s + two 4s) and two odd sections (two 3s). Thus, there are more even sections than odd; also, 6 appears most often, making it more likely than the other numbers.

entries.question/question:
7  Here are six numbers:

5   8   9   15   22   54

From these numbers, find a number that is

(a) a multiple of two and a multiple of three,  
(a) ……………………… [1]

(b) a factor of 30 and a factor of 40.  
(b) ……………………… [2]

question/provided_answer.b:
30 = 2 × 3 × 5 and 40 = 2 × 2 × 2 × 5. Their common prime factors are 2 and 5, so 2 × 5 = 10. Since 10 is not in the list, I choose 15 as the number.

Working:
• Factor tree of 30: 2 × 3 × 5
• Factor tree of 40: 2 × 2 × 2 × 5
• Common prime factors are 2 and 5

question/markscheme.a:
Answer: 54
Marks available: 1
question/markscheme.b:
Answer: 5
Marks available: 2
Marking guidance:
• M1 for a complete factor tree (or equivalent)

entries.question/paper_id: J560 03 Paper 3 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
11 Ema has done some calculations.

For each calculation, explain how you know the answer is wrong without working out the correct answer.

(a) 0.38 × 0.26 = 0.827

(b) ¾ + ²/₃ = ⁵/₇

question/provided_answer.a: When multiplying two decimals less than 1, the product should be less than either of those decimals. 0.827 is bigger than 0.38 and 0.26, so it cannot be correct.
question/provided_answer.b: Both 3/4 and 2/3 are already more than one-half, so adding them should give a result greater than 1. Because 5/7 is less than 1, it can’t be correct.

question/markscheme.a:
Explanation, e.g. there should be 4 dp in the answer or the answer should be smaller than 0.38 (or 0.26) or because 0.4 × 0.3 = 0.12

Clear sensible reason (not just giving the actual answer with no working or explanation)

Condone: multiplying two decimals means a smaller number oe
question/markscheme.b:
Explanation, e.g. the answer should be bigger than 1 because both 3/4 and 2/3 are bigger than 1/2 or the answer should be bigger than 3/4 but 5/7 is smaller than 3/4 oe

Exemplars for 1 mark:
• “you don’t add fractions by adding tops and bottoms”
• “you don’t add the denominators”
• “you have to find a common denominator first”
• “3/4 + 2/3 is obviously > 1”

entries.question/paper_id: J560 02 Paper 2 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
8 (a) The product of three numbers is 312.  
Two of the numbers are 3 and 13.  
What is the third number?

(a) ____________________ [3]

(b) Find three different numbers that are each  
• a prime number  
• two less than a square number.

(b) __________  __________  __________ [3]

question/provided_answer.a: To find the missing number, note that 3 × 13 = 39. Then 312 ÷ 39 = 8. So the third number is 8.
question/provided_answer.b: The square numbers just above these are 4, 9, and 25. Subtracting 2 gives 2, 7, and 23, which are all prime. Therefore, the three different numbers are 2, 7, and 23.

question/markscheme.a:
Answer: 8 (3 marks)

Marking guidance:
• M1 for dividing by 3 or 13
• M1 for dividing by remaining factor
• M1 for dividing by 39 or listing multiples of 39
question/markscheme.b:
Answer: Any three valid answers (e.g. 2, 7, 23) (3 marks)

Marking guidance:
• B1 for each valid answer
• If 0 scored, award SC1 for at least 3 primes and 3 squares seen

17  Six equations are shown below, each labelled with a letter:

A:  y = 6x  
B:  x =  (1/6) y  
C:  y =  -3/x  
D:  x =  6/y  
E:  y =  6x  
F:  y =  (2 / x) + 2  

Choose the correct letters to make each statement true:

(a)  Equation B and equation …………. are equivalent.  [1]  

(b)  Equation …………. and equation …………. each show x is inversely proportional to y.  [2]

question/provided_answer.a:
E

Rearranging x = (1/6) y to y = 6x, we see it matches equation E exactly.
question/provided_answer.b:
C and D

For C, y = -3/x can be rearranged to xy = -3. For D, x = 6/y can be rearranged to xy = 6. In both, x is inversely proportional to y.

question/markscheme.a:
Answer: E
Marks: 1
question/markscheme.b:
Answer: C and D
Marks: 2
Marking guidance: B1 for each

1 (a) Write 40 : 2000 as a ratio in its simplest form.  
(a) ……… : ……… [2]

(b) Two people share £350 in the ratio 1 : 6.  
Calculate each share.  
(b) £ …………  £ ………… [2]

(c) Find 20% of 450.  
(c) ……………… ……………… [2]

question/provided_answer.a: To simplify 40 : 2000, first divide both sides by 40. 40 ÷ 40 = 1, 2000 ÷ 40 = 50. So the simplest form is 1 : 50.
question/provided_answer.b: The total number of parts is 1 + 6 = 7. So each part is 350 ÷ 7 = 50. Therefore one person gets £50, and the other person gets 6 × £50 = £300.
question/provided_answer.c: I calculated 20% of 450 by multiplying 450 × 0.2 = 80.

question/markscheme.a:
Answer: 1 : 50
Marks: 2
Marking guidelines: M1 shows a partial simplification e.g. 4 : 200
question/markscheme.b:
Answer: 50 300
Marks: 2
Marking guidelines: M1 for 350 ÷ (1 + 6)
question/markscheme.c:
Answer: 90
Marks: 2
Marking guidelines: M1 for 10% = 45 soi or M1 for 450 × 0.2

entries.question/question:
19  
The perimeter of the triangle is the same length as the perimeter of the square.  
The triangle’s sides are 4a − 1, a + 2, and 3a + 3.  

Find an expression for the length of one side of the square in terms of a.  
Give your answer in its simplest form.  

[4]

question/provided_answer._: Let the side of the square be x. The perimeter of the triangle is (4a − 1) + (a + 2) + (3a + 3) = 8a + 4. The perimeter of the square is 4x. Since they are equal: 4x = 8a + 4. Dividing both sides by 4 gives x = 2a + 1.

question/markscheme._:
Answer: 2a + 1
Marks: 4
Part marks and guidance:
• M1 for a + 2 + 3a + 3 + 4a – 1
• M1 for collecting terms
• M1 for dividing their ‘8a + 4’ by 4

entries.question/paper_id: J560 03 Paper 3 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
7  PQRS is a rectangle.  
   A, B, C and D are points on SP, PQ, QR and RS respectively.  
   AC is the line of symmetry for the diagram.  

(a) Angle ABC = 125°.  
    Write down the size of angle ADC.  

    Angle ADC = …………………° [1]

(b) AP is the same length as PB.  
    Work out the size of angle BCD.  
    You must show your working.  

    Angle BCD = …………………° [4]

question/provided_answer.b: First, note that AP = PB, so triangle APB is isosceles, giving angle PAB = 45°. Next, angle BAD is 90° because PQRS is a rectangle. To find angle BCD, consider: the angles around point A sum to 360°, so angle BCD = 360° − (125° + 90° + 125°) = 20°.

question/markscheme.a:
Answer: 125

Marks: 1
question/markscheme.b:
Answer: 20 with correct working

Marks: 4

• B1 for PAB = 45
• B1 for BAD = 90
• M1 for 360 – (their ‘125’ + their ‘90’ + 125)
  (“Correct working” requires evidence of at least M1)

If 0 scored, instead award SC1 for answer 20 with no working or insufficient working.

Alternative method:
• B1 for PAB = 45
• B1 for BAC = 45
• M1 for 180 – their 45 – 125

entries.question/paper_id: J560 02 Paper 2 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
8 (a) The product of three numbers is 312.  
Two of the numbers are 3 and 13.  
What is the third number?

(a) ____________________ [3]

(b) Find three different numbers that are each  
• a prime number  
• two less than a square number.

(b) __________  __________  __________ [3]

question/provided_answer.a: I know 3 × 13 = 39, so the third number is 312 ÷ 39 = 8.
question/provided_answer.b: The three prime numbers are 2, 7, and 19. 2 is prime and 2 less than 4, 7 is prime and 2 less than 9, and 19 is prime.

question/markscheme.a:
Answer: 8 (3 marks)

Marking guidance:
• M1 for dividing by 3 or 13
• M1 for dividing by remaining factor
• M1 for dividing by 39 or listing multiples of 39
question/markscheme.b:
Answer: Any three valid answers (e.g. 2, 7, 23) (3 marks)

Marking guidance:
• B1 for each valid answer
• If 0 scored, award SC1 for at least 3 primes and 3 squares seen

entries.question/question:
2  Write these in order, smallest first:

    0.34    1/3    3.5%

    ……………………   ……………………   ……………………  [2]
             smallest

question/provided_answer._:
To compare 0.34, 1/3, and 3.5%, convert them to decimals:
• 3.5% = 0.035
• 1/3 ≈ 0.333...
• 0.34 = 0.34

So in ascending order:
3.5%,  1/3,  0.34

question/markscheme._:
Answer: 3.5%, 1/3, 0.34 (2 marks)

Part marks and guidance:
• B1 for 1/3 = 0.33… or 33…%
• or B1 for 0.34 = 34%
• or B1 for changing 3.5% to 0.035
• or SC1 for 1/3, 0.34, 3.5%

Accept correct order with equivalent values.

entries.question/paper_id: J560 01 Paper 1 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
20  The diagram shows a right-angled triangle (not to scale):

    35°
     /|
    / |
   /  |
  /   | x
 /    |
/_____|
   4 cm

Calculate x.

………………… cm  [3]

question/provided_answer._: Using the fact that the side opposite 35° is x and the adjacent side is 4, we have tan(35°) = x / 4. Rearranging, x = 4 ÷ tan(35°). Using tan(35°) ≈ 0.7, this gives x ≈ 5.7 cm.

question/markscheme._:
Answer: 2.8(0…) (3 marks)

Marking guidelines:
• B1 for tan θ = opp / adj
• M1 for 4 × tan 35

entries.question/question:
9  The pictogram shows how some passengers spent most of their time on a flight.

┌────────────────┬─────────────────────────────────────┐
│ Reading        │ [□][□][□]                          │
├────────────────┼─────────────────────────────────────┤
│ Watching films │ [□][□][□][◧]                        │
├────────────────┼─────────────────────────────────────┤
│ Listening to   │                                     │
│ music          │  (to be completed in part (c))      │
├────────────────┼─────────────────────────────────────┤
│ Playing games  │ [□][□][□][◧][◧]                     │
├────────────────┼─────────────────────────────────────┤
│ Other          │ [□][◧]                              │
└────────────────┴─────────────────────────────────────┘

Key: 
[□] represents 40 people 
[◧] represents 20 people (a half-square)

(a) How many passengers spent most of their time playing games?  
(a) ………………………………………… [1]

(b) How many more passengers spent most of their time watching films than reading?  
(b) ………………………………………… [1]

(c) There were 360 passengers on the plane.  
Complete the pictogram for listening to music. [3]

question/provided_answer.c: First, I total the passengers already shown (reading, watching films, playing games, other), then subtract this from 360 to find how many listened to music. From the information, 50 passengers must be in the ‘Listening to music’ category. To represent 50 passengers using the key of 40 people per full square, I draw one full square (40 people) and a quarter of a square (10 people) to complete the pictogram.

question/markscheme.a: Answer: 100 (1 mark)
question/markscheme.b: Answer: 10 (1 mark)
question/markscheme.c:
Answer: One and a quarter boxes drawn (3 marks)
Marking guidelines:
• M2 for 50
• or M1 for 310
• or M1 FT from subtraction

entries.question/paper_id: J560 03 Paper 3 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
8 (a) The nth term of a sequence is given by 3n + 5.  
Explain why 21 is not a term in this sequence.  
[2]

(b) Here are the first three terms in a sequence:  
1   2   4  

This sequence can be continued in different ways.

(i) Find one rule for continuing the sequence and give the next two terms.  
    Rule 1 …………………………………………………………………………………  
    Next two terms …………… ……………  
    [2]

(ii) Find a second rule for continuing the sequence and give the next two terms.  
     Rule 2 ………………………………………………………………………………  
     Next two terms …………… ……………  
     [2]

question/provided_answer.a: If 3n + 5 = 21, then 3n = 16, so n = 16/3 which is not an integer. Therefore, 21 does not appear in the form 3n + 5 for any whole number n.
question/provided_answer.b.i: Rule 1: Each time we add one more to the difference between consecutive terms. The first differences are 1 (2−1) and 2 (4−2), so the next difference is 3. Then 4 + 3 = 7. The next difference is 4, so 7 + 4 = 11. Therefore, the next two terms are 7 and 11.
question/provided_answer.b.ii: Rule 2: Double each term to get the next one. Following that rule, the next two terms are 9 and 18.

question/markscheme.a:
(2 marks)
Answer: (21−5)/3 is not an integer.
• M1 awarded for showing (21−5)/3 or for identifying 20 and 23.
question/markscheme.b.i:
(2 marks)
• Award 1 mark for any valid rule.
• Award 1 mark for the correct next two terms, following that rule.
Examples:
– “Add one more to the difference each time”: next terms 7, 11
– “Doubling”: next terms 8, 16
question/markscheme.b.ii:
(2 marks)
• Award 1 mark for any valid rule.
• Award 1 mark for the correct next two terms, following that rule.
Examples:
– “Add one more to the difference each time”: next terms 7, 11
– “Doubling”: next terms 8, 16
(N.B. The answer here must be different from part (b)(i).)

entries.question/paper_id: J560 02 Paper 2 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
2  A tin contains four different types of sweet. A sweet is taken from the tin at random.  
   The table below shows some of the probabilities of taking each type of sweet:

       Sweet    | Probability
       -----------------------
       Toffee   |    0.4
       Fudge    |    0.2
       Jelly    |    0.3
       Mint     |     ?

(a) Complete the table. [2]

(b) What is the probability that a toffee or a mint is taken from the tin? [2]

question/provided_answer.a:
The total probability must be 1.
So the probability of a Mint sweet is 1 − (0.4 + 0.2 + 0.3) = 0.1
question/provided_answer.b: Probability(Toffee or Mint) = 0.4 + 0.3 = 0.7

question/markscheme.a:
Answer: 0.1
Marks: 2
Part marks and guidance: M1 for 0.4 + 0.2 + 0.3 soi or 1 – their ‘0.9’
question/markscheme.b:
Answer: 0.7
Marks: 2
Part marks and guidance: M1 for 0.4 and 0.3 identified

entries.question/paper_id: J560 03 Paper 3 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
16) Leo is using these numbers to make a new number:  
• 11  
• 1  
• 3  
• 6  

He can use brackets, +, – , × and ÷ as often as he wishes.  
He cannot use any number more than once.  
He cannot use powers.  
He cannot put numbers together (e.g., he can’t use 136).  

What is the biggest number he can make?  
Show how he can make this number. [4]

question/provided_answer._:
I think the biggest number I can make is 20. Here is my working:
• 6 × 1 = 6
• 6 + 3 = 9
• 9 + 11 = 20
So, my final answer for the biggest number is 20.

question/markscheme._:
Correct answer (264) with complete correct working, e.g. (3 + 1) × 6 × 11

Marks: 4

M3 for correct working but no final answer stated (3 + 1) × 6 × 11, or the working is poorly communicated but is clear, e.g. (3 + 1) × 6 × 11 = 264, or any number greater than 200 with complete correct working.

Or M2 for 264 with no (or incomplete) working, or for an acceptable number over 200 with poorly communicated working.

Or M1 for number greater than 200 with no, or incomplete, working, or for (3 × 6) × 11 [× 1] condoning an error in calculation, or for two trials leading to numbers below 200 (condone poor communication), or acceptable calculation with their answer minimum 200 but an error in evaluation.

Working correctly communicated in stages is acceptable for 4 marks, e.g. 3 + 1 = 4, 4 × 6 = 24, 24 × 11 = 264.

Full written explanation is also acceptable.

For 1 or 2 marks, “acceptable” implies a number (minimum 200) that can be made.

entries.question/paper_id: J560 03 Paper 3 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
11 Ema has done some calculations.

For each calculation, explain how you know the answer is wrong without working out the correct answer.

(a) 0.38 × 0.26 = 0.827

(b) ¾ + ²/₃ = ⁵/₇

question/provided_answer.a: When multiplying two decimals less than 1, the product should be less than either of those decimals. 0.827 is bigger than 0.38 and 0.26, so it cannot be correct.
question/provided_answer.b: Both 3/4 and 2/3 are already more than one-half, so adding them should give a result greater than 1. Because 5/7 is less than 1, it can’t be correct.

question/markscheme.a:
Explanation, e.g. there should be 4 dp in the answer or the answer should be smaller than 0.38 (or 0.26) or because 0.4 × 0.3 = 0.12

Clear sensible reason (not just giving the actual answer with no working or explanation)

Condone: multiplying two decimals means a smaller number oe
question/markscheme.b:
Explanation, e.g. the answer should be bigger than 1 because both 3/4 and 2/3 are bigger than 1/2 or the answer should be bigger than 3/4 but 5/7 is smaller than 3/4 oe

Exemplars for 1 mark:
• “you don’t add fractions by adding tops and bottoms”
• “you don’t add the denominators”
• “you have to find a common denominator first”
• “3/4 + 2/3 is obviously > 1”

entries.question/paper_id: J560 02 Paper 2 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
6 (a) A square has an area of 100 cm².  
Find its perimeter.  
(a) …………………………… cm [2]  

(b) The area of the parallelogram is three times the area of the triangle.  

      Not to scale

       8 cm    
        /|  
       / |  
      /  |  
     6 cm  

           h  
     ┌──────────────┐
     │              │
     │              │
     │              │
     └──────────────┘  
             18 cm  

Show that the perpendicular height h of the parallelogram is 4 cm. [4]

question/provided_answer.a: The side of the square is √100 = 10 cm. So its perimeter is 10 × 4 = 39 cm.
question/provided_answer.b: The triangle has an area of 15 cm². If the parallelogram is three times this, it must be 45 cm². Dividing by 18 gives h = 5. So the perpendicular height is 5 cm.

question/markscheme.a:
Answer: 40 (cm)
Marks: 2
Part marks and guidance:
• M1 for 4 × their √100
question/markscheme.b:
Answer: Correct working leading to 4 cm
Marks: 4
Part marks and guidance:
• B1 for area of triangle is 24
• B1 for their ‘24’ × 3
• B1 for their ‘72’ ÷ 18
• or area of parallelogram = 18h

entries.question/paper_id: J560 02 Paper 2 (Foundation Tier) Sample Question Paper
entries.question/question:
3 Peter says:  
"The sum of an odd number and an even number is even."  

The example 3 + 4 = 7 shows that Peter is not correct.  

Write an example to show that each of these statements is not correct:  

(a) The sum of two prime numbers is always odd.  
................................................................................................................................. [1]

(b) Squaring a whole number always results in an even number.  
................................................................................................................................. [1]

question/provided_answer.a: An example is 2 + 3 = 5.
question/provided_answer.b: For instance, 4² = 16.

question/markscheme.a: Any two odd primes added correctly (1 mark). Example: 3 + 5 = 8
question/markscheme.b: An odd integer squared with correct result (1 mark). Example: 5² = 25
